posts.title: Recaping Startup Career Fair
posts.markdown:
As one ascended the stairs to Norris’s top floor, an uncustomary buzz gradually amplified. The entrepreneurial spirit was tangible on the top floor; the restricted view of the bustling room from the sign-in tables was a source of excitement. Upon signing in, students were set free to explore a room full of opportunities.

Startup representatives packed the room as eager students went from table to table, learning and conversing. If intrigued with the company, students submitted their resume and moved on to the next appealing table. Northwestern student, Navin Gopaul, comments on the comforting environment, “I liked this fair a lot because it is casual and allowed me to talk openly with the employers and get to know what’s important to the organization.” But the fair benefitted more than just students. Talking to Elevate’s representative, Zach Gillean, I understood why students were so enthusiastic about the fair.

When asked what he looks for in a perspective employee, Mr. Gillean answered, “I’m searching for people that are high energy, analytic, and passionate about entrepreneurship.” After attending the Startup Career Fair, I’m assured that Northwestern’s community can provide what Mr. Gillean and other employers desire. It’s inspiring to see entrepreneurship in action.

**--Nate Woods '19**

posts.title: EPIC Recruiting!
posts.markdown:
Hey you, come join the EPIC family.

Did you miss Fall Recruitment? Have no fear, you still have the chance to join the premier entrepreneurial club on campus with EPIC's Spring Recruitment. If you want to build, create, design, or just be epic, join our team and help grow programs like WildHacks, Launch, and NUVC. 

Apply at nuisepic.com/apply! Applications close on April 8th at 11:59PM.

**Come to our last infosession:
Thursday, April 7th @ 7pm: The Garage, Makerspace**

Did you miss Fall Recruitment? Have no fear, you still have the chance to join the premier entrepreneurial club on campus with EPIC's Spring Recruitment. If you want to build, create, design, or just be epic, join our team and help grow programs like WildHacks, Launch, and NUVC.

Apply at nuisepic.com/apply! Applications close on April 8th at 11:59PM.

Come to our last infosession: Thursday, April 7th @ 7pm: The Garage, Makerspace

posts.title: LAUNCH is launching!
posts.markdown:
The evening of Sunday, February 28th, was a peaceful evening for most. But for the eleven teams that make up the EPIC Launch cohort, the evening was crunch time. The Launch program, run by a team of passionate EPIC members, is Northwestern’s first student-run accelerator, and the cohort were expected to put together pitch-perfect presentations on their startup ideas and their progress, and answer some hard-hitting questions about revenue streams, potential competition, and their next steps.

The ideas were extremely diverse, to say the least. Some students wanted to serve better food on campus, and some students wanted to create better a music experience for everyone. Some teams had steady progress, all the way back from the fall when the Launch program kicked off, and other teams had pivoted their ideas to something very different, as recently as the night before the presentations. The bottom line, however, was that each team represented enormous potential for growth, endless hours of hard work, and newly discovered opportunities to make the world a better place, and this is what we wanted them to do in the first place.

posts.title: SharED CEO Boddy Powers visits the Garage
posts.markdown:
I got the pleasure to sit down with one of Northwestern’s own Garage residents, ==Bobby Powers==. Powers started off a tech consultant at Deloitte before finding himself at Kellogg pursuing a MBA with the intentions of possibly pursing entrepreneurship. He is now a founder of SharEd, an education venture that hopes to improve early education in developing countries by lowering costs of preschool resources and delivering a high quality curriculum. SharEd believes that education is a right; quality education shouldn’t just be afforded to high-income families. Currently SharEd is running its curriculum in India and looking to scale up to 20-30 schools for the upcoming school year. The focus in India came from internal ties within team members to this country; Powers himself was able to teach English in Bangladesh during his time in college and some team members have kinship there. With fewer barriers to entry, Powers and his team launched their pilot in India and continue to grow there.
 
Powers’s advice to younger entrepreneurs is to be action oriented because that will be your biggest strength. 

* He believes that the toughest part of entrepreneur is getting started. While SharEd was not completely ready for their initial pilot, it was more important for Powers that they get started right away instead of waiting for everything to be perfect and then get started. 

* He challenges entrepreneurs to worry less about bad branding and the inability to recover from failures because a few costumers is but a small percentage of the total market you are trying to serve.

* Instead, Powers focuses on the importance of putting yourself out there in order to learn instead of being crippled by the fear of failure. 

 
Being a resident at the ==Garage==, Powers and SharEd are able to utilize the resources there. Personally for Powers and his team, they believe that mentorship is the most important resource the Garage provides. This community of support is able to advise and direct each other to resources. Generally, Powers believes that the Garage is able to lower the barrier to entry to being an entrepreneur. He states, “If everyone is trying to come out of businesses from their dorm rooms, you don’t see it and it seems unattainable.” The Garage is a central hub where you can see what’s happening around campus and lowers initial intimidations that are felt. He observes that progressively the Garage is becoming more and more packed. “The entrepreneurship bug is catching on.

**Sharon Wei**

posts.title: EPIC Fall newbies
posts.markdown:
After 10 days of deliberate consideration and close discussion, EPIC is more than excited to welcome 24 new members to the family! We were thrilled by the extremely competitive applicant pool, and every decision was made with caution and confidence. We recruited people from Medill, Weinberg, SoC, SESP and McCormick in different classes, and we can’t wait to bring EPIC to the next level with their diverse, creative inputs.
 > “I really look forward to learning new skills and gaining more coding experience, and more importantly, I want to make new friends in the inspiring EPIC community.” Says Murphy Angelo ’19, a new member of Tech team.

This spring, EPIC launched two new programs: Venture and General Membership. Venture is a brand-new Pre-Orientation program designed for incoming Freshmen, which aims at exposing them to the Northwestern entrepreneurial environment and connecting them to available resources. At the same time, in response to the general public voice of making EPIC more accessible and resourceful, we introduced General Membership with zero entrance barrier to all Northwestern students. Members are encouraged to attend workshops and events hosted by EPIC, and they can sit down in EPIC All-Hands meetings and hear about entrepreneurship news at Northwestern.

> “We give full autonomy to every team member with hopes that they can make a direct impact through EPIC. We definitely have a strong and dynamic new cohort, and I’m excited to see how they will grow Northwestern’s entrepreneurial community.” Says Jessica Tan ’17, the co-president of EPIC. 

Uniting 7 different teams and around 60 members, three-year-old EPIC is expanding rapidly and providing more opportunities for wildcats. As the spring recruitment comes to an end, we are more than ready for the new challenges and possibilities with our new members!

Uniting 7 different teams and around 60 members, three-year-old EPIC is expanding rapidly and providing more opportunities for wildcats. As the spring recruitment comes to an end, we are more than ready for the new challenges and possibilities with our new members!

posts.title: Learn more about RECESS
posts.markdown:
RECESS, a national pitch competition where students can take the stage with their own start-ups, held their Spring 2016 Tour School event here in Northwestern’s Garage on Tuesday, April 12th. This competition is unique in that it is multi-tiered in a bracket style similar to March Madness. Five teams are selected from each participating school to compete and the winner will advance to the Region Semifinals Round. There, students will compete with three winning Campus Qualifier teams in the region and the winning team will move onto the National Semifinals Round in Los Angeles. The top three will continue to the finals where the winning team will receive automatic entry into the National Finals round of the Capital Championship and a chance at the $250,000 cash grant prize. The competition evaluated
1. how unique the business was, 
2. the clarity of the explanation of their business, 3. their understanding of the market, 
4. the ability to penetrate said market, 
5. and their overall pitch with included four minutes of pitching and four minutes of Q&A.

I got the opportunity to sit down with Ahren Alexander, the winning team’s founder. Audiovert’s produce, the hexon, is a customizable speaker system that customers can make their own by manipulating the color size, power, and price. Ahren believes that Audiovert was able to win due to their ability to demonstrate traction in their idea, their experience of putting their actual product in the hands of their customers, and his own extensive knowledge of the market due to being a music enthusiast for most of his life. Their biggest challenge moving forward is mastering their distribution channels, how to get the word out, and solidifying the entire process of getting their hexon from building to shipping. Audiovert will be taking on the winning team from UIC and ITT at Concord Music Hall on April 22nd.
For any comments and questions, feel free to reach out to Ahren Alexander at ahren@audiovert.com. To learn more about RECESS and how to apply in the future, here is their webpage http://recess.is/application/


**--Sharon Wei '17**

posts.title: Third Starter Dinner hosed by EPIC
posts.markdown:
On Thursday May 5th, we will be hosting our third Starter Dinner at 6:30PM in The Garage at Evanston Campus, Northwestern University. Hosted by EPIC and GSV, Starter Dinners is a dinner series during which students can learn more about entrepreneurship from and be inspired by entrepreneurial alums. In the past, we have successfully connected students to the community of entrepreneurial Wildcats and promoted mentorship among all the participants. If you are involved in entrepreneurship and interested in sharing your experiences by attending a Starter dinner in the future, we'd love to have you!  Please fill out your information at the following link: 
**http://goo.gl/forms/QxgHkkMNXz**

posts.title: BrewBike is brewing
posts.markdown:
You may have heard by now about BrewBike, the student coffee startup launched by freshmen garage residents Lucas Philips and Brammy Geduld. The idea started out as NU Student Coffee, Northwestern’s first student run coffee shop, and developed into BrewBike, a trike serving cold brew coffee to the Northwestern community. I had the chance to sit down with Lucas and learn about the progression of their idea from a coffee shop to a bike with a cooler, in addition to his entrepreneurial experience as a whole.

Lucas said the he came up with the idea for NU Student Coffee after he joined Launch in the fall. At first, he felt lost in terms of what problem to address, and, like many other people, often thought of startups as being “tech-focused”. Once he began to consider starting something in a different industry, he remembered hearing about student-run coffee shops on tours at other colleges and realized there wasn’t one here at Northwestern. Lucas and Brammy starting working with Northwestern’s food service provider, Sodexo, on their original plan of redesigning Café Bergson, and housing NU Student Coffee there. Lucas described working with Sodexo as more of an “intrepreneurial” experience than an entrepreneurial one. They wanted to create something from scratch and come up with their own processes for deciding things such as how to run payroll, analyze finances, and make and serve coffee, instead of using Sodexo’s pre-established processes. After moving away from Sodexo, NU Student Coffee had to scale back and rethink their idea. They began to ideate, at one point coming up with a farmer’s market-style coffee tent, and eventually decided on BrewBike.

Lucas believes an entrepreneur is not just someone who comes up with an idea but can also implement and execute ideas that improve on what already exists. He “used to think [entrepreneurship] was just coming up with a cool idea and going for it”, but learned there was a lot more work in terms of compliance, in addition to things like branding and how the actual product is being served.        

> “Brammy and I were very naïve in the beginning”, he says, “We thought they were just going to give us a space and we were going to be able to redesign it and just start doing our thing”. 

Lucas feels that as their idea changed directions and progressed, they were able to figure out what exactly they wanted to learn and turn their vision into a venture in which they can learn those things and also provide value to the Northwestern community. Lucas and Brammy are looking forward to getting multiple bikes and expanding the team as much as necessary, including people who can help out with things like logos, accounting, and the actual process of serving the coffee.

To learn more, check out their Indiegogo page at https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/brewbike-northwestern-s-first-mobile-coffee-shop#/

posts.title: LAVA AND ZIP LINES...IT'S EPIC RETREAT!
posts.markdown:
EPIC team members packed the vans, everyone guessing about how the weekend would unfold. The ride, full of music and conversation, came to an end as Loyola Retreat Center’s pretty complex revealed itself amongst the trees. We met the center’s staff and were assigned to our rooms. After dinner and name games, members intermingled and played a multitude of games. Distance from everyday responsibilities lead to a relaxed atmosphere and allowed for new relationships to develop. Time flew by unnoticed until yawns began to interrupt discussion. Slowly, the group dwindled as people returned to their beds at the end of a long day.

The day started with a big breakfast, then the EPIC team went outside for various team building exercises. Limits were tested on the ropes course, while others enjoyed the thrill of zip ling. On the ropes course that made one queasy to look down, we could complete the obstacles, relying on your partner, while suspended in the air. Everyone shared in the exhilaration of reaching the ground alive and matured. Down the path, teammates oversaw each other’s safety on the zip line and bonded over the excitement and view of the area.

Teams reunited over a much needed lunch to exchange tales of their activities and meet members from other teams. The lunch room was filled with a noticeable energy from the group. After a nice break, different teams were formed for indoor games intertwined with discussion. Side by side, members guided a marble using short wooden pieces to a cup on the other side of a large room. The marble fell and frustration was felt, but members collaborated and formed the safest and most efficient solution. Then, members traversed and balanced on rubber islands down the “lava” covered hallway. The last members of the linked line were cheered on by their teammates at the finish line. To conclude, minds and body were tested as we carried a teammate through the faces of a plastic cube frame balanced on a bucket. While extremely challenging, everyone took flight and got through the cube.

The mood declined as the group realized the end was upon us. Farewells were exchanged and people returned to their cars. I appreciated the restful return trip but was saddened knowing I must wait a year for another eventful retreat.

-Nate Woods, '19

posts.title: <fun> HackNight </fun>
posts.markdown:
**HackNorthwestern, Women in Computing and IEEE** collaborated and hosted their fifth Hack Night this quarter last Wednesday at 7p.m. Around 25 hackers gathered at the Garage to participate in the event.

> One of the presidents of HackNorthwestern, Diane Liu, said “HackNorthwestern is a student group that serves the hacker community on campus by providing free resources to anyone who wants to learn how to code.” 

The three organizations host weekly Hack Nights aiming to introduce a wide variety of topics including web development, mobile development and more in a hands-on manner.

The Hack Night last Wednesday focused on chrome extensions. Leader of the Hack Night, William Xiao, said an extension called Drumpfinator inspired him to give a presentation on chrome extensions. Drumpfinator replaces all instances of “Trump” with “Drumpf” in the chrome browser. He said he found the idea very interesting and decided to show everyone how to make an extension that could replace any set word to another.

After everyone got a taste of food (catering from Pita Inn) and settled down with their laptops open, the presentation officially started. In order to accommodate those who have less experience in coding and programing, William first explained the function and use of JavaScript, an important program in creating the dynamic and interactive parts of a website. Then William moved on to illustrated the detailed steps of coding a chrome extension. Though it is assumed that all participants have some sort of programming experience, there were also mentors present to help anyone with any problems. The event lasted for about two and a half hours.

Diane said when she first became interested in computer science a couple years ago, she felt there was not a lot of beginner resources on campus. She says she wishes to to “make the learning curve less steep” through holding the weekly Hack Nights.

> “The goal is for Hack Nights is to be a safe space where anyone who wants to learn how to code can come in, eat some great food, and spend an hour or two learning a new skill with the help of mentors who've done it before.” Diane said.

HackNorthwestern will continue to hold Hack Nights every Wednesday at 7 p.m. and people with all levels of programming skills are welcomed. If you are free on Wednesday night, come to the garage for a fun Hack Night with free food!
